metadata.title: Gene expression kinetics of the yellow head virus in experimentally infected Litopenaeus vannamei

location.addrLine: Me¤ xico Correspondence: Dr F Vargas-Albores

abstract.text: The yellow head virus (YHV) has been reported to be one of most pathogenic viruses for cultivated shrimp; however, serious problems have only been reported in farms in south and southeastern Asian. Recently, a YHV strain was detected in Litopenaeus vannamei cultivated in Mexican farms that lacked virus-associated mortalities or epizooties, and the animals were apparently healthy. The identity of the virus was con¢rmed by sequencing replicative and structural proteinencoding regions and comparing with homologous virus sequences. Phylogenic relationships and genetic distances were also determined and, although some di¡erences were observed, an in£uence on virulence was uncertain. In addition, the expression levels of several transcripts (3CL PRO , POL, GP64 and GP116) were evaluated by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction during an experimental infection. Although the transcript showed varying kinetics, viral genes were expressed in infected L. vannamei, demonstrating the replicative capability of thisYHV strain.

body_text.text: Shrimp aquaculture has undergone a rapid expansion in recent decades. However, bacterial and viral infections represent a major constraint a¡ecting the industry due to signi¢cant economic losses. The yellow head virus (YHV) and the white spot syndrome virus have been reported to be the most dangerous viruses for cultivated shrimp (Durand,Tang & Lightner 2000) , and besides virulence, the epizooties are typically associated with poor management and/or environmental conditions. Yellow head virus epizooties cause up to 100% mortality 3^5 days after virus introduction (Wongteerasupaya, Sriurairatana, Vicker, Akrajamorn, Boonsaeng, Panyim, Tassanakajon, Withyachumnarnkul & Flegel 1995) , and an e¡ective treatment is not available. In addition to its high virulence and infectiveness, YHV is a very risky virus (Boonyaratpalin, Supamattaya, Kasornchandra, Direkbusaracom, Aekpanithanpong & Chantanachookin 1993 ), as it is also able to naturally infect other shrimp populations, which can then act as natural reservoirs (Lu,Tapay, Brock & Loh1994; Ma, Overstreet & Jovonovich 2009 ).

body_text.text: Based on its morphology,YHV was originally classi-¢ed as a Baculovirus (Boonyaratpalin et al.1993) . However, by genomic taxonomy, YHV is classi¢ed as an Okavirus, a member of the Roniviridae family that characteristically has a (1)ssRNA genome (Cowley, Dimmock, Wongteerasupaya, Boonsaeng, Panyim & Walker 1999; Cowley, Dimmock, Spann & Walker 2000; Sittidilokratna, Hodgson, Cowley, Jitrapakdee, Boonsaeng, Panyim & Walker 2002; Gonza Ł lez, Gomez-Puertas, Cavanagh, Gorbalenya & Enjuanes 2003; Gorbalenya, Enjuanes, Ziebuhr & Snijder 2006; Pasternak, Spaan & Snijder 2006) . The insertion of YHV into Nidovirales was supported by similarities in both its genomic organization and its replication mechanism (de Vries, Horzinek, Rottier & de Groot 1997; Pasternak et al. 2006; Sittidilokratna, Dangtip, Cowley & Walker 2008) . In Nidovirales, includingYHV, the key biochemical machinery for virus replication is typically encoded by a large discontinuous open reading frame (ORF), referred to as ORF1a and ORF1b, which overlap in a small area containing a À 1 ribosomal frameshift (Cowley et al. 2000; Sittidilokratna et al. 2002; Gorbalenya et al. 2006) . Other genomic regions include ORF2, which encodes the nucleocapsid and envelope proteins (Cowley, Dimmock & Walker 2002; Jitrapakdee, Unajak, Sittidilokratna, Hodgson, Cowley, Walker, Panyim & Boonsaeng 2003; Cowley, Cadogan, Spann, Sittidilokratna & Walker 2004; Gorbalenya et al. 2006; Sittidilokratna, Phetchampai, Boonsaeng & Walker 2006) ; ORF3, which encodes the precursors for the envelope glycoproteins GP116 and GP64 Jitrapakdee et al. 2003) ; and ORF4, which is interrupted by multiple stop codons (Nadala Jr,Tapay & Loh 1997; Sittidilokratna et al. 2008) .

body_text.text: Even though considerable progress has been made in the characterization of theYHVgenome (Sittidilokratna et al. 2008) , information on viral gene expression during infection is limited. Using speci¢c monoclonal antibodies, expression of the envelope (GP64 and GP116) and nucleocapsid (N) proteins was monitored in ¢ve species of prawns (Macrobrachium rosenbergii, Macrobrachium lanchesteri, Macrobrachium sintangense, Palaemon styliferus and Penaeus serrifer) that had been experimentally infected (Longyant, Sithigorngul, Chaivisuthangkura, Rukpratanporn, Sithigorngul & Menasveta 2005) . Penaeus serrifer, P. styliferus and M. sintangense exhibited mild to moderate YHV infection symptoms 3 days postinjection, and the infection severity was sig-ni¢cantly reduced after10 days. Conversely, M. rosenbergii and M. lanchesteri did not show symptoms, even though viral proteins were detected in the ¢rst hour post-infection, suggesting a natural resistance toYHV infection and/or the ability to e⁄ciently eliminate the virus. A similar response was observed in Penaeus (Metapenaeus) a⁄nis and Pseudocalea brevicornis, suggesting that some prawns are able to gradually eliminate the virus by an unknown mechanism (Longyant, Sattaman, Chaivisuthangkura, Rukpratanporn, Sithigorngul & Sithigorngul 2006) . Interestingly, experimentally infected Litopenaeus vannamei and Litopenaeus stylirostris show symptoms and mortality pro¢les similar ot those of naturally infected cultivated Penaeus monodon (Lu, Tapay, Loh, Brock & Gose1995; Spann, Cowley,Walker & Lester 1997; Pantoja & Lightner 2003) .

The establishment of viral replication kinetics from early stages of infection is fundamental to understanding the infectious capacity of YHV including those strains that apparently do not a¡ect cultured shrimp. A YHV strain (YHV-Lv) was isolated from L. vannamei cultivated in Mexican farms without virus-associated mortalities or epizooties, and with the animals apparently being healthy (de la Rosa-Velez, Cedano- Thomas, Cid-Becerra, Mendez-Payan, Vega-Perez, Zambrano-Garcia & Bonami 2006) . Therefore, the aim of this study was to sequence the genome of theYHV-Lv strain and compare it with the sequences of virulent strains to determine genomic di¡erences that could explain the lack of infectivity and/or virulence in L. vannamei. In addition, the replication capability of the YHV-Lv strain was determined by monitoring the expression of genes involved in viral replication and those encoding structural proteins during development of the experimental infection.

body_text.text: The AmericanYHV strain (YHV-Lv) was obtained from apparently healthyYHV-positive L. vannamei cultivated in shrimp farms from the Paci¢c coast of Me¤ xico (de la Rosa-Velez et al. 2006) . The AsianYHVstrain (YHV-Pm), recovered from P. monodon during a YHV epizooty in Thailand in 1996 and reproduced in Litopenaeus setiferus, was provided by the Ecosystemes Lagunaires Laboratory, Universite¤ Montpellier 2, France.

To determine genomic sequences,11primer sets were designed based on the GenBank sequences for YHV and GAV (GenBank accession nos. AF227196, AF148846, AY052786; DQ067891, AF540644). These regions correspond to genes associated with viral replication, such as the chymotrypsin-like protease 3CL PRO (3CL PRO ), peptide 1 (PEP1), RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, helicase (HEL) and structural components, including motif1 (M1), nucleocapsid protein p20 and the spike glycoprotein that contains glycoproteins GP116 and GP64, as well as the no-encoding ORF4. In addition, the overlapping region (ORF1a/1b) was ampli¢ed with primers published by Sittidilokratna et al. (2002) (Table 1) .

Pleopods from animals infected with YHV-Lv or YHV-Pm were homogenized, total RNA was puri¢ed by TRIzol (Gibco BRL, San Francisco, CA, USA) and cDNA was synthesized using oligo-dT and reverse transcriptase SuperScript TM II (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA), following the manufacturer's instructions. Viral genes were ampli¢ed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (iCyclerTM thermocycler, Bio-Rad, Carlsbad, CA, USA) using speci¢c primers. The ¢nal reaction volume of 25 mL contained 2.75 mL10 Â PCR bu¡er (50 mM KCl, 10 mM Tris-HCl; pH 8.3), 1 mL of 10 mM dNTPs, 0.75 mL of 50 mM MgCl 2 , 1 mL of 10 mM each primer, 0.25 mL of Taq DNA polymerase 5 U mL À 1 (Go-Taq s , Madison, WI, USA) and 2 mL cDNA. The optimal annealing temperature for each primer pair was determined previously by gradient temperature, and the PCR conditions were: one cycle of 94 1C/5 min; 30 cycles of 94 1C/30 s, primer annealing temperature/30 s and 72 1C/1min; followed by extension at 72 1C for 7 min. Polymerase chain reaction products were separated by electrophoresis in a 1% agarose gel, stained with ethidium bromide (1 mg mL À 1 ) and visualized under UV light.

Polymerase chain reaction products were puri¢ed using the Wizard s PCR Preps DNA Puri¢cation System (Promega, Madison, WI, USA), and thoroughly sequenced in both directions by SeqXcel s (DNA Sequencing Services, San Diego, CA, USA). The sequences from each strain were edited using Chromas Pro V 1.14 before comparison using discontinuous megablast against the nr/nt nucleotide database (NCBI, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/blast/ Blast.cgi). Fragments ampli¢ed with primer pairs HEL1, HEL2 and HEL3 were assembled using the program BIOEDIT V7.0.9 (Hall 1999) .

All sequences from YHV-Lv and YHV-Pm were aligned using CLUSTAL X (Thompson, Gibson, Plewniak, Jeanmougin & Higgins 1997 ) and compared individually with the corresponding viral region from otherYHV strains (Cholburi,Thailand and Chachoengsao) isolated from Thailand farms (GenBank accession nos. EU487200, AF148846, AY052786, EF156405, AF148846, DQ067891 and AF540644) and sequences from GAV (GenBank accession no. AF227196), another member of the Nidovirales family. Sequences from the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) virus (GenBank accession nos. DQ898174 and AY502924) and transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGV) (GenBank accession nos. AY335549, DQ201447 and Y00560) were also included as external groups. Genetic distances were calculated using the program MEGA 4.1 (Kumar, T a , primer annealing temperature; qPCR , quantitative PCR; PCR, polymerase chain reaction; ORF, open reading frame.

To estimate the adequate viral inoculum for 100% survival up to 96 h, di¡erent dilutions (1:2^1:50) of homogenized pleopods were prepared from YHV-Lv-infected shrimp (L. vannamei) as described previously (de la Rosa-Velez et al. 2006) . Groups of 10 juvenile shrimp L. vannamei were inoculated in the third abdominal segment with 20 mL of di¡erent viral dilutions of YHV-Lv. As a control,10 animals were inoculated with negative-YHV shrimp tissue. Typical symptoms of YHV infection and mortality were monitored up to 125 h postinoculation.

body_text.text: To determine the best tissue for the detection of viral genes, 10 juveniles (18^20 g) were infected with YHV-Lv, and samples from haemocytes, the haepatopancreas, muscle, gill, intestine and pleopods were taken at di¡erent times post-inoculation. Total RNA was isolated from each tissue, and cDNA was synthesized as above. Peptide 1, as a representative viral replication gene, was ampli¢ed by PCR, using the following conditions: one cycle of 94 1C/5 min; 30 cycles of 94, 56 1C/30 s and 72 1C/1min; followed by extension at 72 1C for 7 min. Polymerase chain reaction products were separated by electrophoresis in 7.5% acrylamide gels and silver stained (Sanguinetti, Dias Neto & Simpson 1994) .

body_text.text: Ampli¢ed and sequenced fragments corresponding to the polymerase, the protease 3CL PRO and two glycoproteins (GP116 and GP64) were cloned into pCR2.1 s -TOPO s vector, and these vectors were used to transform One Shot s Mach1 TM -T1R Competent Cells (TOPO TA Cloning s , Invitrogen). After being expanded in LB medium, the plasmid was puri¢ed using the Wizard s SV 96 Plasmid DNA Puri¢cation System (Promega) and its concentration and quality were estimated by optical density at 260 and 280 nm. To con-¢rm, each insert was sequenced in both directions by Millegen s Biotechnologies (Labe' ge, France), and was then used to prepare standard curves for quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qPCR).

To follow viral infection, 150 shrimp (average weight, 20 g) were inoculated in the third abdominal segment with 20 mL of a 1:25 viral dilution. Pleopods from 10 L. vannamei were sampled at di¡erent times (1.5, 3, 6, 12, 24, 48,72 and 96 h) and pooled, and total RNA was puri¢ed. In addition, pleopods from ¢ve animals were sampled at 24, 48, 72 and 96 h, and the total RNA was individually puri¢ed. In both cases, cDNA was synthesized by reverse transcriptase, as described above.
Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction was performed using a Lightcycler

Yellow head virus has been responsible for devastating mortalities in cultured shrimp, causing a negative impact on this industry. Although P. monodon is the most a¡ected shrimp, other penaeids have also been reported to be susceptible to di¡erent grades of virulence. For example, when a mixed culture of P. monodon, Pterocarpus indicus and Penaeus merguensis was a¡ected by YHV, signi¢cant mortalities were observed only in P. monodon, and this phenomenon was explained as a host speci¢city (Mohan, Shankar, Kulkarni & Sudha 1998 ). In addition, YHV has been found in non-cultivable shrimp (P. merguiensis, Acetes sp., P. styliferus and P. ensis) without typical disease symptoms (Durand et al. 2000) . This apparent host speci¢city and wide distribution in natural non-cultivable shrimp populations is indicative of the immense natural reservoirs and their role in YHV dissemination. An apparently non-virulent strain of YHV,YHV-Lv, was recovered from healthy L. vannamei cultivated in Mexican farms, where YHV-associated epizooties have not been reported (de la Rosa-Velez et al. 2006) , leading to questions about the di¡erent virulence of YHV-Lv and otherYHV strains. Also, the Asian strain, YHV-Pm, was recovered from P. monodon during a YHVepizooty in Thailand, in 1996, and it has been experimentally reproduced in L. setiferus.

The ¢rst step was to sequence several portions of the viral genome. The genomic regions (3CL PRO , POL, HEL, GP64, GP116, N, PEP1, ORF1a/1b and M1) to be sequenced were selected based on the importance of these genes in viral metabolism, the availability of similar sequences and/or similarity to related viruses (Cowley et al. 2000 Jitrapakdee et al. 2003; Ziebuhr, Bayer, Cowley & Gorbalenya 2003; Sittidilokratna et al. 2006 ). In addition, primers published by Sittidilokratna et al. (2002) were used for ampli¢cation and sequencing of the region containing the slippage and involving an RNA pseudo knot located immediately downstream of this slippery sequence. The optimal annealing temperature was determined by temperature gradient, for each primer pair. Most annealed between 56 and 58 1C, while temperatures of 42 and 66 1C were used for ORF4 and GP116 respectively (Table 1) . After PCR, the corresponding fragments were sequenced as many times as necessary to obtain complete and error-free sequences. The sequences ampli¢ed with primer pairs HEL1, HEL2 and HEL3 were assembled by overlapping extremes. The sequences were deposited in GenBank with accession nos. DQ978355 to DQ978363 and EU977577 to EU977584. The ampli¢ed sequences corresponding to GP116, N, POL, 3CL PRO and ORF4 were identical in both Lv and Pm strains and only slight di¡erences were observed in GP64 (0.1%), ORF1ab (0.43%) and HEL-M1 (0.04%).

Each sequence from YHV-Lv and YHV-Pm was compared with those reported for other strains (Cholburi, Thailand and Chachoengsao), and sequences of GAV were included as references. When available, se-quences from either the SARS virus or TGV were included as an external group. After CLUSTAL alignment, genetic distances were determined (Table  2 ) and phylogenic trees (Fig. 1) were generated using neighbour joining and bootstrap. In both cases, a close phylogenic relationship could be established amongYHV strains, forming a compact group (genetic distances 0.0085^0.0182), which is associated with GAV but di¡erent from the external groups. In sum, all determined sequences from YHV-Lv and YHV-Pm were identical (99.93% similar), and both showed high similarity (98%) to the corresponding sequences reported for other strains of YHV (Cholburi and Chachoengsao). There is also a moderate similarity to GAV, another Nidovirales. Thus, the high similarity found in a large portion of the virus genome con¢rms the identity of the YHV strain isolated in Mexican farms.

The Nidovirales glycoproteins (GPs) have a central role in the induction of the host immune response and are targets for protective immunity (Spaan, Cavanagh & Horzinek 1988) . They have also been demonstrated to determine virulence (Phillips, Chua, Lavi & Weiss 1999; Almazan, Gonzalez, Penzes, Izeta, Calvo, Plana-Duran & Enjuanes 2000) because they are key proteins in the recognition of host cells and the fusion of the virus to the cellular membrane (de Vries et al. 1997; Gonza Ł lez et al. 2003; Gorbalenya et al. 2006) . Similar functions have been reported for the surface glycoproteins GP64 and GP116 of YHV and GAV Jitrapakdee et al. 2003) . Focusing the genomic analysis on the GP116-encoding region, signi¢cant di¡erences could be observed between any YHV strain and the less aggressive pathogen GAV, suggesting the role of this protein in virulence. body_text.text: Because the YHV-Lv strain shows low infectivity towards L. vannamei under natural conditions, experimental inoculation was used to con¢rm the occurence of the viral replication. To determine viral gene expression through an experimental infection, the viral doses for inoculation were established as the maximal viral dilution able to induce all disease symptoms, but still showing 100% survival of animals up to 96 h. This assay was performed by inoculation of 90 apparently healthy animals with di¡erent viral dilutions (10 animals per dilution) and the time for maintaining 100% of living animals was recorded. As expected, with high doses (up to dilution 1:10), mortality was observed in the ¢rst 36 h; however, when dilutions 1:20 and 1:30 were used, the ¢rst death of an animal was recorded at 84 and 108 h respectively. By non-linear regression analysis, the 1:24 dilution was determined to be the highest viral concentration where100% survival could be observed at 96 h after inoculation (Fig. 2) , and then this dilution was used in all subsequent experiments. Next, the best tissue for sampling was determined by inoculation of 10 animals with 20 mL of adequate viral dilutions, and the ampli¢cation of the PEP1gene was performed in haemocytes, the haepatopancreas, muscle, gill, gut and pleopods obtained at 24 and 96 h postinoculation. Polymerase chain reaction products were separated on acrylamide gels and silver stained, which is a fast, inexpensive and sensitive method (Fig. 3a) . Ampli¢cation was not observed in the haepatopancreas and gut (Fig. 3b) , while a moderate signal was obtained in the muscle and gill. However, intense ampli¢cation of the PEP1 gene was observed in pleopods from 36 to 96 h (Fig. 3c ) and haemocytes at 24 and 96 h (Fig. 3d) . Although haemocytes and pleopods showed the most intense signal, the isolation of total RNA from haemocytes requires a careful manipulation of the sample to avoid degranulation or cellular lysis. Thus, pleopods were selected as the sampling tissue for monitoring the expression of 3CL PRO , POL, GP116 and GP64 as a measurement of the replicative capability of the YHV-Lv.

The selected genes, 3CL PRO , POL, GP116 and GP64, are relevant in viral replication and interaction with the host cell. In Nidovirales, 3CL PRO is responsible for the post-translational release of key proteins for replication (Ziebuhr, Snijder & Gorbalenya 2000; Ziebuhr et al. 2003; Gorbalenya et al. 2006; Sittidilokratna et al. 2008) , while the polymerase is the most conserved gene and thus has been used to propose a common ancestor for all Nidovirales (de Vries et al.1997; Cowley et al. 2000; Sittidilokratna et al. 2002) . As in all Nidovirales studied, the structural glycoproteins, GP116 and GP64, are involved in the interaction with host cells (Gonza Ł lez et al. 2003; Jitrapakdee et al. 2003; Gorbalenya et al. 2006) , and speci-¢cally, GP116 has been associated with the pathogenic behaviour of several YHV strains (Sittidilokratna et al. 2008 ). According to the results shown in Fig. 4 , three phases could be de¢ned: (a) the ¢rst Figure 2 Determination of viral doses. Di¡erent viral dilution was inoculated and the time for maintaining 100% of living animals was recorded. The maximal viral dilution to reach 100% survival up to 96 h postinoculation (discontinue line) was estimated from a non-linear regression (solid line). phase from1.5 to 24 h postinoculation; (b) the second phase from 24 to 72 h postinoculation, is characterized by a fast increment in gene expression (4 two orders); and (c) the third phase from 72 to 96 h postinoculation, shows a slow increment in gene expression. The gene expression pro¢le is compatible with the viral replication model, initially proposed by Ellis and Delbruck (1939) . The ¢rst phase, associated with virus adsorption and/or penetration, and the third phase, related to virus assembly and release, characteristically show low gene expression, while the second phase is di¡erentiated by a fast increment in gene expression probably due to virus replication.

In addition, ¢ve shrimp were sampled during the second phase (24, 48 and 72 h postinoculation) and analysed individually. Although comparable expression pro¢les could be established, quantitative di¡erences were detected (Fig. 4 ) among individuals and, consequently, high dispersion was obtained. For example, at 96 h postinfection, the number of copies of GP64 ranged from 10 5 to 10 8 , although discrete dispersion was observed for GP116 (10 5^1 0 6 ) and 3CL PRO (10 7^1 0 8 ). Then the curve slope from 24 to 72 h, representing the expression rate, was calculated for each gene and each shrimp. Equimolecular concentrations of 3CL PRO and POL coding sequences are expected because they are transcribed together as the replicase polyprotein 1ab, which is encoded by two large overlapping ORFs (ORF1a/1b) that contain the À 1 ribosomal frame shift. After transcription, 3CL PRO and POL functional proteins are produced by site-speci¢c cleavage of the replicase polyprotein 1ab.

However,3CL PRO was highly expressed almost immediately after viral inoculation, increasing to 2.08 Â 10 5 copies mL À 1 at 1.5 h, while POL showed a modest expression (ffi 10 2 copies mL À 1 ). Afterwards both transcripts displayed similar increasing rates, but maintained the 3CL PRO /POL ratio around 10 3 . Likewise, GP116 and GP64 are encoded by ORF3, but di¡erent concentrations of their corresponding transcripts were detected, mainly between 24 and 48 h, when the concentration of the GP64 transcript rapidly increased (Fig. 4) . These disparities could not be explained due to the poorly understood replication and transcription mechanisms in Nidovirales where sub-genomic mRNA and double-stranded RNA intermediates, as well as the poorly described non-structural proteins seem to be implicated (Pasternak et al. 2006; Enjuanes, Sola, Zun ì iga & Moreno 2007) . The importance of 3CL PRO for Nidovirales replication has been corroborated by the silencing of this gene in YHV-infected P. monodon, which caused a strong inhibition of viral replication, whereas silencing GP116 and GP64 was less e⁄cient (Ziebuhr et al. 2003; Tirasophon, Roshorm & Panyim 2005; Yodmuang,Tirasophon, Roshorm, Chinnirunvong & Panyim 2006; Tirasophon, Yodmuang, Chinnirunvong, Plongthongkum & Panyim 2007) . As shown in Fig. 4 , 3CL PRO is highly expressed early, perhaps because this protein is required for creating other functional viral proteins by proteolytic cleavage (Ziebuhr et al. 2000) . On the other hand, transcripts of the structural glycoproteins GP116 and GP64 also showed di¡erent concentrations. This could be due to di¡erences in the hydrolytic action of RNases where polyA tails have a degradation-protective role (de Vries et al. 1997; Pasternak et al. 2006) .

body_text.text: Although each gene showed di¡erent expression rates, the mean of the ¢ve genes expression rate is the sum of the events that occur during the viral replication. In this way, two shrimp (Org 3 and Org 5) showed a lower viral expression rate (Fig. 5 ) and this could be associated with individual resistance to virus attachment. Expression of viral genes is associated with viral replication and disease severity; hence, organisms with high viral replication should be more susceptible than those with lower rates of virus replication. Considering that viral replication is complete 24^72 h after inoculation, the slope in this time frame is representative of the gene expression rate and could be used as a measurement of viral susceptibility. Although further experiments are required, viral replication analysis could be used to establish shrimp infection status and expression levels associated with disease.
